etymologies: Old English; earliest use found in The Aldhelm Glosses. Cognate with Old Icelandic roði, Norwegian rode, Swedish regional rudi, ruda, roda from an ablaut variant (zero-grade) of the Indo-European base of red

definitions: Red colour, especially of the complexion or lips; redness; ruddiness. rare after 16th century.

etymologies: late 15th century (in an earlier sense). Origin uncertain; apparently related to (later) redd although the relationship between the forms is difficult to account for

definitions: The spawn of a frog or toad (also toad rud).

etymologies: Old English (in an earlier sense). From rud. Compare ruddy and red

definitions: To make red or ruddy; to redden. Usually in passive. Chiefly archaic and English regional in later use.
In sheep farming: to mark (a sheep) with ruddle.
